Learn how to set up your Terraform code repo using GitHub."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Setting up AWS for Terraform","timeRequired":"PT4M30S","description":"This course will use AWS in this course so that Terraform will have something to manage. This video covers the basics of setting up access for Terraform."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform Cloud","timeRequired":"PT5M37S","description":"Terraform Cloud is a user-friendly way to use Terraform without having to install anything locally. Set up a workspace in Terraform Cloud using your GitHub repo and AWS credentials."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform plan","timeRequired":"PT3M","description":"When you uploaded your starter code, Terraform cloud automatically ran Terraform plan. You can see what changes Terraform is going to try to make by looking at the Terraform plan."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"First Terraform run","timeRequired":"PT3M17S","description":"Before learning about theory, jump right in and see Terraform in action. Learn how to use the starter code to do your first Terraform run."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"How Terraform works","timeRequired":"PT4M1S","description":"Dig into the details of how Terraform actually manages your infrastructure."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform states","timeRequired":"PT1M37S","description":"Terraform tracks what's going on with your infrastructure by keeping a record of infrastructure states. Learn about how state works and how to explore state files in Terraform cloud."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Editing your code","timeRequired":"PT3M53S","description":"Learn how to make some changes to your Terraform code and see the results when Terraform runs."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Understanding Terraform errors","timeRequired":"PT4M23S","description":"Learn how to edit some of the code in your repo to generate an error and learn how to read and understand Terraform error output."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Resources","timeRequired":"PT2M39S","description":"Resources are the basic building blocks of Terraform code. Explore the base syntax for Terraform resources."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Basic resource types","timeRequired":"PT3M54S","description":"Go deeper with resources by learning about several common resource types."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform style","timeRequired":"PT2M18S","description":"Get a quick review of the recommended style conventions to keep your Terraform code readable and maintainable."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Security group","timeRequired":"PT7M24S","description":"To keep your resources secure, learn how to configure a security group."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Using modules","timeRequired":"PT3M25S","description":"Learn how Terraform code can be structured into reusable modules."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform registry: Providers","timeRequired":"PT2M58S","description":"The Terraform registry is the first place you should look when starting a new Terraform project. Explore examples of supported cloud providers."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform registry: Modules","timeRequired":"PT8M4S","description":"The resource types from the AWS provider allow you to deploy individual resources, and modules allow a higher level of abstraction. Learn how to search for a module in the Terraform registry and use it to simplify your code."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Get ready to scale","timeRequired":"PT3M55S","description":"For a customer-facing web app, it's essential to have multiple environments for development and QA. Learn to refactor code to so it's ready to support multiple networks."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Expanding your installation","timeRequired":"PT10M33S","description":"Modern enterprise web applications usually need more than a single instance. You can use official AWS modules to configure autoscaling and load balancing so that your application can respond to changes in load."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Variables","timeRequired":"PT2M52S","description":"Sometimes, you need your infrastructure to be a bit more dynamic and flexible. Learn how to use variables in your code and on the command line."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Split out your data","timeRequired":"PT11M15S","description":"Before you can make your code modular, you need to replace hard-coded values with variables. Walk through a simple technique for doing that quickly."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Modularize","timeRequired":"PT5M34S","description":"You've seen how to use existing modules. In this video, learn how to convert your code to a module that can be used to provision separate environments."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Deploying environments","timeRequired":"PT7M43S","description":"Now that your code is modular, use it to deploy several infrastructure environments by configuring separate workspaces in Terraform cloud."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Cleaning up: Terraform destroy","timeRequired":"PT5M30S","description":"Since you're working with real cloud resources, it's important to clean up when you're done. Learn how to use the Terraform destroy command to delete all of the infrastructure you've provisioned."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform CLI","timeRequired":"PT9M2S","description":"Terraform has a fully featured command line interface. Walk through the tool and discover how to match most of the functionality of Terraform cloud."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Next steps","timeRequired":"PT2M46S","description":"This course is just the beginning of your Terraform journey. IaC allows for efficient, automated, and scalable infrastructure management, reducing manual errors, and increasing the ability to scale and manage infrastructure across different environments."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Introduction to infrastructure as a code with Terraform","timeRequired":"PT1M37S","description":"In this video, learn how to define IaC and discover how Terraform can be used to implement IaC. This topic is important because it introduces you to the fundamental concepts of IaC and demonstrates how Terraform can simplify infrastructure management, improve deployment speed and reliability, and enable collaboration among teams."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform use cases in public and private cloud","timeRequired":"PT4M31S","description":"In this video, learn how to identify the specific use cases for Terraform in both public and private cloud environments. This topic is important because it enables you to understand the versatility of Terraform in managing infrastructure across multiple cloud providers and on-premises, providing practical insights for real-world applications."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Multicloud and provider-agnostic benefits","timeRequired":"PT2M38S","description":"In this video, learn how to explain the benefits of using Terraform for multicloud and provider-agnostic deployments. By understanding the benefits of multicloud and provider-agnosticism, you can design and implement infrastructure that is resilient, flexible, and avoids vendor lock-in."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Example template to create a virtual network in Azure","timeRequired":"PT4M43S"},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"The benefits of Terraform state","timeRequired":"PT5M31S","description":"In this video, learn about the benefits of using Terraform state in managing infrastructure as code. Understanding the benefits of Terraform state is essential for managing infrastructure as code consistently and efficiently, enabling better collaboration, change management, and version control."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Install and version Terraform providers","timeRequired":"PT9M48S","description":"In this video, learn how to install and version Terraform providers to enable infrastructure management across different cloud providers and services. By learning to install and version Terraform providers, you can effectively manage infrastructure dependencies and ensure compatibility across different projects and environments."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"How Terraform finds and fetches providers","timeRequired":"PT5M24S","description":"In this video, learn how Terraform finds and fetches providers. Knowledge is very helpful because it enables you to understand the process of locating and downloading Terraform providers, which is essential for successful infrastructure management using Terraform."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Plugin-based architecture of Terraform","timeRequired":"PT1M55S","description":"In this video, learn how to explain the plugin-based architecture of Terraform. This knowledge is important because understanding the plugin-based architecture of Terraform allows you to better understand how Terraform works and how to effectively extend its functionality through plugins."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Write Terraform configuration using multiple providers","timeRequired":"PT11M44S","description":"In this video, learn how to write a Terraform configuration that uses multiple providers. This a crucial skill as it enables you to manage the infrastructure resources across multiple providers, providing flexibility and avoiding vendor lock-in."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Import existing infrastructure into Terraform state","timeRequired":"PT10M22S","description":"In this video, learn about the process of importing existing infrastructure into Terraform state and the best practices for doing so. Importing existing infrastructure into Terraform state saves time, reduces human error, and improves infrastructure management consistency."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Understanding verbose logging","timeRequired":"PT3M15S","description":"In this video, learn how to effectively use the Terraform state command to view the current state of their Terraform-managed infrastructure. Understanding how to view Terraform's state is essential to managing infrastructure effectively, as it allows for a better understanding of the current state of resources and changes made to them, enabling quick troubleshooting and error resolution."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Enable verbose logging","timeRequired":"PT3M39S"},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"What is the Terraform module and its uses?","timeRequired":"PT5M51S","description":"In this video, learn how to define and use Terraform modules to abstract infrastructure resources and reuse code in a modular and scalable way. Understanding Terraform modules enables users to modularize infrastructure code, reduce duplication, promote reusability, and achieve better maintainability and scalability of infrastructure."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Publishing modules and uses of Terraform module","timeRequired":"PT2M32S"},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Module source options","timeRequired":"PT8M","description":"In this video, learn how to contrast and use different module source options, including the public Terraform registry, to simplify Terraform configuration and enable reuse. In this video, learn how to contrast and use different module source options, including the public Terraform registry, to simplify Terraform configuration and enable reuse."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Interact with module inputs and outputs","timeRequired":"PT8M21S","description":"In this video, learn how to interact with module inputs and outputs to customize module behavior and retrieve data produced by the module. Understanding how to interact with module inputs and outputs is critical in creating reusable and flexible infrastructure code, enabling the creation of highly modular and customizable infrastructure."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform core workflow","timeRequired":"PT9M54S","description":"In this video, learn about the Terraform workflow and its three main phases—write, plan, and create—for managing infrastructure as code. Understanding the Terraform workflow enables better management of infrastructure by allowing for the creation of a plan that can be reviewed before making changes, ensuring consistency, and reducing errors in the infrastructure."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Steps of the Terraform core workflow","timeRequired":"PT11M20S","description":"In this video, learn how to describe the Terraform Core workflow, including the steps of Terraform Init, Validate, Plan, and Apply. Understanding the Terraform Core workflow is essential for successfully using Terraform to manage infrastructure and ensures that the desired infrastructure state is consistent with the actual infrastructure state."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Use terraform destroy","timeRequired":"PT2M32S","description":"In this video, learn how to use the terraform destroy command to remove Terraform-managed infrastructure. Understanding how to destroy Terraform-managed infrastructure allows for efficient resource management, cost savings, and the ability to start fresh with infrastructure management."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Default local back end","timeRequired":"PT2M5S","description":"In this video, learn about the concept of a default local back end in Terraform and how it works. Understanding the default local back end is crucial for efficiently managing the Terraform state on the local machine and simplifying the Terraform workflow, ultimately leading to better infrastructure management."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Benefits and challenges of the default local back end","timeRequired":"PT1M55S"},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Remote state storage","timeRequired":"PT7M1S"},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"State locking in Terraform","timeRequired":"PT6M13S","description":"In this video, learn about the importance of state locking in Terraform to prevent concurrent access to the same state file. State locking is a critical aspect of Terraform, as it helps prevent conflicting updates and ensures that only one person can make changes to the state file at a time, thus avoiding data corruption and improving collaboration."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Remote state back-end options","timeRequired":"PT2M46S","description":"In this video, learn how to differentiate between different remote state back-end options in Terraform and choose the most suitable option for their infrastructure. Understanding and choosing the right remote state backend option can ensure the consistency, security, and scalability of Terraform's infrastructure, especially in a team-based or multi-user environment."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Manage resource drift and Terraform state","timeRequired":"PT2M51S","description":"In this video, learn how to identify resource drift and discover how to manage Terraform state to keep it in sync with the actual infrastructure. Understanding how to manage resource drift and Terraform state ensures infrastructure consistency, prevents configuration drift, and simplifies troubleshooting, ultimately leading to cost savings and better resource utilization."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Uses of variables","timeRequired":"PT8M38S","description":"In this video, learn about the use of variables and outputs in Terraform to make the configuration more dynamic and reusable. to Advanced Terraform","timeRequired":"PT54S"},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"What you should know","timeRequired":"PT1M13S"},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform review and terminology","timeRequired":"PT3M11S"},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Exercise files","timeRequired":"PT5M33S"},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Practical Terraform","timeRequired":"PT1M13S","description":"Learn about a common real-world Terraform use case, in which a DevOps engineer must design a new Terraform configuration for an existing application."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Google Cloud and Terraform: Tools and setup","timeRequired":"PT6M43S","description":"Set up the essentials to use Google Cloud, including Visual Studio Code or the Cloud Editor, as well as the Google Cloud SDK."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Designing a cloud infrastructure in Terraform","timeRequired":"PT2M15S","description":"Review the application architecture of the sample application used throughout the course to identify the resources that will be required."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform configuration overview","timeRequired":"PT3M16S","description":"Create the initial \"lift-and-shift\" Terraform configuration, based on the design created earlier, that will deploy the sample application to Google Cloud. Review the resources created in this simple configuration."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Deploying the Terraform configuration","timeRequired":"PT6M24S","description":"Now that the initial configuration is created, deploy it to Google Cloud and confirm that it works."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Review deployed resources","timeRequired":"PT1M8S","description":"Examine the resources in the Google Cloud Console, and use the gcloud CLI command to confirm that everything was deployed as desired."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Destroying resources","timeRequired":"PT2M33S","description":"Use the Terraform destroy command to reverse the deployment, deleting the resources that were applied. If something goes wrong and the destroy command doesn't work for some reason, find out how to destroy resources manually."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Input variables","timeRequired":"PT5M52S","description":"Hashicorp Configuration Language uses variables to store data. Variables can hold a number of different data types and are declared and accessed depending on their type and other characteristics. Learn about the difference between input and output variables and how they're used."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Using input variables","timeRequired":"PT6M23S","description":"Variables can be used throughout a configuration to drive its behavior. Different types of variables can be used to set simple or complex values, and can combine with expressions to perform looping and conditional operations."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Output variables","timeRequired":"PT5M50S","description":"Output variables are used to report data from the deployment of a configuration. These \"return values\" can be used in a variety of ways."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Sensitive data","timeRequired":"PT4M10S","description":"Variables often contain values that are sensitive data, such as usernames and passwords. Terraform provides features that prevent this kind of data from \"leaking\" into logs and command history."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Looping with count","timeRequired":"PT7M59S","description":"Terraform supports simple looping constructs using count, which is a simple numerical counter. Looping is an excellent technique for simplifying code and reducing the number of lines needed to complete a configuration."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Looping with for_each","timeRequired":"PT3M26S","description":"Terraform supports looping with for_each, which can be used to iterate over a list, map, or set. Each iteration of the loop can access values in the iterator object. This is a powerful technique for complex loops that can consolidate a lot of code into a single stanza."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Expressions and functions","timeRequired":"PT6M33S","description":"Hashicorp Configuration Language supports simple expressions and predefined functions."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Introduction to modules","timeRequired":"PT2M38S","description":"Terraform modules are self-contained \"sub-configurations\" that are used to create packages of reusable configurations. Modules are written much like full configurations, with input and output variables."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Using Terraform modules","timeRequired":"PT3M55S","description":"The term \"Infrastructure as Code\" implies that we're writing code to define infrastructure. Well-written code is well-organized code, with clear separation of concerns between distinct modules. Examine how we've already been using Terraform modules, and how they can be used to make our configuration clearer and more adaptable."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Analyzing a module","timeRequired":"PT7M52S","description":"Modules are very powerful tools. There are many community and vendor-produced modules for GCP and other platforms that will simplify Terraform configurations and reduce the number of lines of code needed. Eventually, configurations may grow complex enough to benefit from a custom module. The best way to learn how to write custom modules is to analyze one. Learn how to deconstruct the Terraform service account module used previously to understand how it works."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Custom modules","timeRequired":"PT4M24S","description":"Terraform developers can create their own reusable modules to simplify configurations and reduce repetition."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform remote state overview","timeRequired":"PT2M7S","description":"Terraform state is a binary representation of the actual resources provisioned by a Terraform configuration. Storing Terraform state and a lock file in a remote location allows a team of engineers to collaborate on a configuration and execute it safely."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Deploying backend resources","timeRequired":"PT1M55S","description":"Configurations that use the remote-state feature for collaboration use a resource called a backend. The backend resources must be deployed separately prior to the deployment of the main configuration."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Deploying a remote state configuration","timeRequired":"PT3M34S","description":"Configurations that use remote state require a slightly different set of commands to prepare them for deployment. Examine those differences and learn about the configuration settings required for the AWS S3 backend."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Multiple environment configurations","timeRequired":"PT2M31S","description":"The software development lifecycle is used to deploy software to a set of environments, each with a specific purpose. Developers use development environments to do initial \"smoke testing\" and quality checks. QA environments are used for more advanced testing and integration, and Production environments serve business users. A single Terraform configuration can be set up to handle these variations, deploying different resources for each environment."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform CI/CD options","timeRequired":"PT3M44S","description":"There are many tools and techniques available to create Terraform CI/CD pipelines. We'll review several, discuss their relative benefits, and cover the tradeoffs between them."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Terraform Cloud setup","timeRequired":"PT9M48S","description":"Hashicorp provides Terraform Cloud as a centralized, SaaS-based managed platform for users of Terraform. We'll cover the setup of a Terraform Cloud account, defining an Organization, and an overview of Terraform Cloud."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Deploying with Terraform Cloud","timeRequired":"PT1M59S","description":"Engineers use Terraform Cloud to run Terraform in a managed environment. Terraform Cloud can serve as a backend for remote state and can run plan/apply commands remotely using its compute resources."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"GitOps CI/CD setup","timeRequired":"PT9M27S","description":"GitOps is a method used to trigger CICD pipelines by making changes to branches in a git repository. This video walks through the process of using Terraform to \"bootstrap\" a CICD pipeline. A single Terraform configuration will create projects in Google Cloud, as well as Workspaces in Terraform Cloud, configured and ready for a GitOps deployment pipeline."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"GitOps CI/CD with Terraform Cloud","timeRequired":"PT9M8S","description":"Terraform Cloud is purpose-built to support CI/CD Terraform pipelines. The demo configuration will be updated to support a branching strategy for multiple environments. We'll use Terraform cloud to demonstrate how changes to a configuration can be developed, tested in a low-level environment, and then promoted to Production."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Deprecating resources","timeRequired":"PT6M25S","description":"Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) provides fundamental resources such as Compute Engine VMs. Groups of virtual machines that run the same code can be deployed as a group using Managed Instance Groups. This chapter demonstrates how to modify an existing configuration to go from a \"simple\" IaaS service to a more managed IaaS service with a built-in load balancer. In this video, learn about VMs and how they can be created."},{"@type":"Syllabus","name":"Create a VM in the portal","timeRequired":"PT9M16S","description":"Most people prefer a point and click approach to scripting when it comes to administrative tasks.
